profileAlternative.name: Neil Mitchell
profileAlternative.headline: Programmer at Facebook
profileAlternative.summary: I'm a Haskell programmer who lives in Cambridge with my wife Emily and son Henry. I have a PhD in Computer Science from York University, working on making functional programs shorter, faster and safer. Since then I've worked with F# at Credit Suisse, Haskell/F#/C++ at Standard Chartered and Haskell/F# at Barclays Bank, taking the lessons of functional programming and applying them in finance. I currently work for Digital Asset, but all content and opinions are my own. I'm a strong believer in the functional approach, finding the combination of conciseness, static-typing and testability to offer significant advantages.

positions.title: Summer of code project with Haskell.org

given.text:
I worked with Shayne at Digital Asset. He joined the team with an O'Caml background, but aware he was going to do Haskell. Rather than just any Haskell, I dropped him in at the deep end as our GHC compiler hacker. He was able to implement a number of GHC extensions, mostly in the parser/desugarer, but some which involved the type checker, and work with the community to get them upstream. Shayne took on the challenge of GHC and learnt Haskell at the same time - no mean feat. Shayne is a genuine "nice guy" who has made the office a more pleasant environment. I look forward to our paths crossing again in future.
…
See more

I worked with Paul at Digital Asset, where one of the things Paul did was produce material for external audiences via the company blog. Paul was relentless in taking our raw thoughts and ideas, polishing them, and giving it an overarching story that matched the company message. Paul managed to serve as an effective conduit to communicate complex engineering topics into a business-friendly message, and also served as a valuable sounding board to get the perspective "from the other side". Throughout, Paul always stayed away from the limelight himself, leaving others to pick up the credit - an admirable trait.
…

profile.name: Neil Mitchell
profile.headline: Programmer at Facebook

I have a PhD in Computer Science from York University, working on making functional programs shorter, faster and safer. Since then I've worked with F# at Credit Suisse, Haskell/F#/C++ at Standard Chartered and Haskell/F# at Barclays Bank, taking the lessons of functional programming and applying them in finance. I currently work for Digital Asset, but all content and opinions are my own. I'm a strong believer in the functional approach, finding the combination of conciseness, static-typing and testability to offer significant advantages.
